author: Jamie Pandaram
title: Smith, Steve Waugh, former, current Australian captains, advice, batting order
text:
TO become a great Australian captain, Steve Smith must close off his inner circle, legendary skipper Steve Waugh has advised.
Next week in Brisbane, the new Test captain leads his first mission since being appointed fulltime leader after Michael Clarke’s retirement when Australia hosts New Zealand, and Waugh says Smith’s tenure cannot be a popularity contest.
“The one thing I learned about captaincy is that you can’t please everyone,” Waugh said.
STARS: NSW names scary Sheffield Shield squad
VIDEO: the shot that stunned the world
“You’ve got to have one or two close advisers that you listen to, and trust your own instincts.
“You get a lot of different people offering you advice, from former players to the man on the street, and that’s great but you need to be able to block it out and trust in your close-knit circle and your lieutenants.”
Steve Smith during the failed Ashes series. Source: Getty Images
Smith will be supported by vice-captain David Warner, a brash and at times unpredictable character who brings an intriguing style to the leadership table. “It’s good to have characters in the team,” Waugh said. “So long as everyone is on the same page, heading in the same direction, the team will do well.”
Waugh also panned the common-held theory that as Australia’s best batsman, Smith must bat in the crucial No. 3 position that the side has struggled with since Ricky Ponting’s retirement.
“I don’t buy into that idea, I think it’s outdated, you bat where you feel comfortable,” Waugh said.
“Some guys like batting with the tail, other guys don’t mind hanging around before they get out there, and some guys want to be out there straight away facing the new ball.
“I think Usman Khawaja at No. 3 and Steve Smith at No. 4 will work for Australia.”
Steve Smith hammers NSW home in Matador Cup final 1:15 Play video
Cricket: The New South Wales Blues have claimed victory in the Matador Cup final against South Australia, largely thanks to a huge innings from skipper Steve Smith, that saw him smash six sixes.
Fox Sports 25 Oct 2015 Sport/Cricket/Highlights The line-up of Australia’s team for the first Test against the Kiwis remains a mystery, with several veterans having retired and a changing of the guard taking shape. It is tipped that West Australian rookie Cameron Bancroft will be handed a Test debut at just 22 years, to open the batting with Warner, while Khawaja will come in as first drop.
“I’m not as well credentialed as others, I haven’t seen Cameron Bancroft play for example, but I’ve spoken to Justin Langer and he says he’s the real deal, he’s got a great temperament, good technique, loves batting, likes a tough situation and is a good kid,” Waugh said.
“That’ll do me as a referral from Justin Langer. He seems like a good choice.
“Khawaja I think is ready to play for Australia again, Joe Burns deserves an opportunity, he got two 50s last time he played a Test (58 and 66 against India in this year’s Sydney Test).”
Asked what he expects of the West Indies, who tour Australia from December, Waugh didn’t mince his words.
“Not much, don’t buy tickets for day four or day five,” he said.
“To see guys like Chris Gayle prefer to play Twenty20 games over Test cricket doesn’t send a great message to the younger generation.”
